markdownRemark.html:
Summary

Master key computing concepts, coding basics and video game design philosophy. Students will use Java, the Greenfoot library, and Tynker to learn computer science theory, syntax, and object oriented coding.

Course Highlights

LEARN THE INDUSTRY STANDARD

Begin to program in Java one of the industry-standard programming languages that is ubiquitous across a wide range of sectors. Also the students will be encouraged to think about what makes a good video game. They will be introduced to the online software Tynker where they will explore the capabilities of making a simple game. By the end of the course the students will have created their very own video game.

Using User-Friendly library

Start your game development journey using the Greenfoot environment and Tynker designed to support new programmers.

A CRITICAL NEW SKILL

Learn to program which will be one of the key skills needed for jobs in the 21st Century

Course Overview

We teach Java using the Greenfoot platform, developed at the University of Kent. Greenfoot makes coding interactive, easy and fun, providing a supportive environment for the creation of 2D graphical games and simulations. Students will learn coding concepts such as variables, functions and classes, as they go from game consumer to game creator. Our goal is for each participant to feel confident coding, as they undertake original projects and gain familiarity with the Java environment. We also show students the tools and resources available so they can continue learning and developing independently with Java after the course.

This is an excellent first coding course for teens aged 12+ and no previous programming knowledge is required.

What you will learn

  1. Introduction to common Java programming environments
  2. Equip students to debug their code and work out how to help themselves when they run into problems
  3. Creating a simple game AI
  4. Core Coding Principles including Variables, loops, if statements, and functions
  5. Common game design ideas and principles
  6. How to create and use simple game assets
  7. Programming Design Patterns and how to make reusable code
  8. How video games are structured
  9. To understand different types of video games
  10. To appreciate the important features of making a good game
  11. To learn the Tynker environment, using drag and drop coding and logical thinking.
  12. Develop understanding of core computing concepts such as loops, functions etc
markdownRemark.excerpt: This is an excellent first coding course for teens aged 12+ and no previous programming knowledge is required.  BOOK THIS COURSE

frontmatter.title: Game development and Design with Java and Tynker
